paper_title.ja: わが国における職業性上肢障害の発生状況(共著)

paper_title.en: National survey on occupational upper limb disorders in Japan.
National survey on classification for supervision of pneumoconiosis (2)

description.en:
During the term of 1994, with the support of the Ministry of Labor, we carried out a national survey on the classification for supervision of pneumoconiosis among persons engaged in dust work or persons having been engaged in dust work. A statistical analysis was performed using 22,685 copies of statements certifying the results of pneumoconiosis examination. The summary of this survey is as follows.
In respect to classification for chest radiographs, category I (PR1) ranked first (82.1%) and it was followed by PR2, PR4A, PR3, PR4B and PR4C. The PR1 was most prevalent in almost all age groups.
With respect to evaluation of pulmonary function, 98.5% of subjects were classified as F(-) or F(+), and 1.5% persons were classified as F(++). In periodical examination 0.2% were classified as F(++), while in voluntary examination 18.4% were classified as F(++).
The mean age of 710 persons affected by complications was older than that without complication. Secondary bronchitis and pulmonary tuberculosis formed 94.1% of the total number of complications.

paper_title.ja: 労働衛生管理の機能的構造論

paper_title.en: Function and Structure of Occupational Health Care Management

description.en: Death records maintained from 1971 through 1980 by the All-Japan Laundry and Dry-cleaning Association (AJLDA) aspart of a death benefits program were utilized in a proportional mortality study. 1, 711 death certificates were classified according to the B List or the Eighth Revision of the ICD. Data on smoking and drinkine habits and history of exposure were obtained by questionnaire from the families of AJLDA members who died from 1979 through 1981. Expected deaths were cakulatcd for five-year age groups by applying the proportional mortality of Japanese males and females for 1975 or 1980 to the total number of deaths among cleaning workers. Expected deaths over a broader age range were calculated by summation. The statistical significance of the difference between observed and expected deaths was determined by a Mantel-Haenzel one degree of freedom summary chi square. The most significant finding was an excess of deaths from “other forms of heart disease” and “other diseases of the liver” among dry cleaning workers, regardless of personal habits, with a history of exposure to organic solvents. © 1985, Japan Society for Occupational Health. All rights reserved.
